Artificial trees in the 20th century were all little more than collections of bottle brushes in my opinion. Even today a decent artificial tree will run close to a thousand dollars but when they are taken care of they are a bargain that can last 15 or 20 years. I have a k-mart going out of business sale tree that cost a little over two hundred 7 years ago and is just now starting to lose it's luster. Already I have found that replacing it with a look-a-like is going to be difficult at any price. The tips of the needles are frayed to make a more realistic and lightly frosted appearance that is not paint that doesn't flake off every where.

You know. You really gotta ask yourself. Is this really the wiser option to natural tree if you have to choose one or the other? I mean really think about it. Most regular christmas trees are farmed in a way that is renewable mostly these days. These fake trees use mined metals, synthethic plastics whose base compounds often come from endangered trees or are less renewable, among other materials. Some of them arguably weigh more and use up more material and resources in general as well. Plus whatever those sprays and paints are.

Just interesting is all. In my mind it just seems hard to justify the idea that these are somehow better choices for the environment I guess in a big picture sense. I would love to see environmental impact data for it so we can make a confirmed better choice. I mean my choice is no tree in the first place, but for those who just have to have one.
I can't help but to think that those long pvc strips break apart when being drug along in the process I bet its a real pain in the butt for the workers sometimes.

Here's the way the "real" artificial trees are made...
https://youtu.be/wD5m6vhLV-A

Wanna make your fake tree look real? Don't put the branches where the instructions tell you to put them. Exchange a few branches with branches of other layers. In the end you'll have an irregular looking tree that looks a lot more realistic than if you followed the directions.
